author: barnabasbusa
content: <@552133098075193354> would you mind including EIP-6122 (Forkid checks based on timestamps) https://eips.ethereum.org/EIPS/eip-6122 in the https://github.com/ethereum/execution-specs/blob/master/network-upgrades/mainnet-upgrades/shanghai.md#eips-considered-for-inclusion list? Also could we get a tracker for 6049? Would be good to have client versions with all 6 EIPs merged before we go for sepolia fork.

author: timbeiko
content: So, we usually don't include non-core EIPs in the hard fork spec, but I'm not against doing it. Just curious what client teams think!

author: timbeiko
content: Re: 6049, what do you think the tracker should track ðŸ¤” ? Because it's just a deprecation warning, there isn't really anything for clients to do

author: barnabasbusa
content: Don't they have to add the deprecation warning? ðŸ˜„

author: timbeiko
content: I think it's up to them if/how they want to do it. IMO it's more valuable for infra providers to add this, as that's where it gets "seen", i.e. solidity, etherscan,etc.

author: _shemnon
content: Generally I haven't seen clients provide warnings to smart-contract layer issues, as they are all expected to be indistinguishable at runtime.  For 6049 I don't see anything for client to do except for maybe a line in release notes. Any value of "here, we warned you" belongs not in client release notes but in EIPs, IMHO.

author: _shemnon
content: I also see EIP-6122 as not tied to a hard fork.  The last similar one, Eth/66 (eip-2481) was not tied to a hard fork and shipped independently.  A tracker would be useful but I don't think it's a go/no-go for a hard fork like, say, PUSH0 is.  The negative impact is to the client and not to the whole network.

author: _shemnon
content: The other 4 EIPs are all merged, per the spec tracker - https://github.com/ethereum/execution-specs/blob/master/network-upgrades/mainnet-upgrades/shanghai.md#implementation-progresss

author: timbeiko
content: Right, maybe we should have a Core EIP that says "we're now using a timestamp on the EL"?

author: timbeiko
content: which isn't about the peering, but focused on "the fork's changes will trigger at timestamp X, not block Y (or TTD Z)"

author: _shemnon
content: Yes, that is the real impact of 6122 is that timestamps are a one-way door for fork activation.
